I used universal reference because CPU code does
`params.template chip<0>(indices(i)) = updates.template chip<0>(i)`
where the LHS is a rvalue.  If I used a pointer, I would have to first store the LHS in a temporary variable, then pass its address.  Besides the code looking ugly, it may also be less efficient.

It felt like universal reference is designed to solve exactly this problem.  But, there's a simple workaround, which is to store the LHS in a temporary variable, then use plain old references.  I did this now.  PTAL.

I will look into the thread-safety next.  Thanks for pointing to Thrust.  I also realized how to do range checks efficiently now without temporary overwriting data - just write a fast range check kernel.  I'll do that as well.
